awd_titl_txt: Reconstruction Theorems, Brauer Groups, and Algebraic Vision
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is the study of shapes that can be defined using polynomial equations. It has immense expressive power, leading to its incorporation into numerous applied and pure mathematical disciplines. It is an ancient subject, experiencing several flowerings over centuries. Many recent breakthroughs in mathematics rely on algebro-geometric techniques. In its classical form, algebraic geometry plays an essential role in photogrammetry and computer vision, yielding key computational techniques and algorithms that are run billions of times per day all over the world. In its modern form, it is a cornerstone of cryptography, internet communications, and national security. It is a crucial technical tool in modern number theory.

The PI will study problems in several areas of the subject. He will continue his work on derived categories and reconstruction results, focusing on the properties of filtered derived equivalences and on new topological reconstruction techniques, analogous to classical results of Torelli, Gabriel, and others, that have been developed by the PI and his collaborators. He will expand the study of the Brauer group from varieties to rigid analytic spaces, aiming to establish foundational results for rigid spaces that extend known results for classical analytic spaces. He will also continue his study of the algebraic geometry of computer vision using modern techniques, building on work done by the PI and collaborators in recent years. This has potential uses in the development of new algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused research on a range of topics related to a core mathematical structure of our world. This core is called algebraic geometry, the study of the shapes that can be defined using polynomial equations. The PI and his collaborators found the first non-linear generalization of a fundamental result from 1918, more than 100 years later. The PI discovered a new approach to a certain kind of universality phenomenon for projective space. Finally, he and his students and collaborators continued their study of the basic geometric structure of computer vision, including producing new approaches to important problems with applications in every-day life. This work gives us deeper insight into the basic properties of polynomials and their vanishing sets, from both theoretical and practical perspectives. 

The new non-linear discovery by the PI and his collaborators was sparked by a failed attempt at proving a very abstract conjecture about something called the derived category. After pondering this arcane monster for years, the PI and Olsson realized that there is a related vein of mathematics. They followed this vein and recruited more mathematicians to join them. The final result of this desultory journey is the realization there is a natural non-linear generalization of one of the foundational results of 20th Century mathematics, the Veblen-Young theorem. The Veblen-Young theorem gave birth to a range of ideas in mathematics, from modern axiomatic geometry to model theory. While Veblen-Young can be construed as capturing the essence of linear geometry, the PI and his collaborators realized that something called the Zariski topology similarly captures the essence of non-linear geometry. This work has been called "pioneering", and it is a perfect example of how crucial NSF support is for American mathematics. By supporting speculative research divorced from immediate commercial or security interest, the NSF makes it possible for us to follow the winding paths that lead to breakthroughs.

Another area where the PI made progress during this period of funding has to do with the algebraic variety that is, in some ways, the most beguiling for its ordinariness. The space we grow up in, the space with free coordinates and no other constraints -- also called projective space -- is so free to do as it pleases that it seems to contain every mathematical fact within it. The PI studied a way to make that notion precise in the context of a theory called cohomology. This theory is essentially a fancy way to turn complex problems into linear problems. In studying the universality of projective space from the point of view of cohomology, the PI discovered that a new way to approach a famously thorny result on the finer structure of cohomology classes. Essentially, one can leverage the freeness of projective space to gain fine structural knowledge of any algebraic variety, no matter how constrained it is. 

The PI has long been interested in the geometry of computer vision and the use of modern techniques to develop new algorithms and refine old algorithms. In the course of this funded project, the PI discovered new ways to approach old problems and new algorithms to do key calculations that are happening billions of times each day on Earth. These insights came from the most abstract of methods, in collaboration with researchers from the University of Washington and Google. The PI and his collaborators wrote a paper on the fundamental geometric structure of computer vision problems. This work is ongoing and has the promise to contribute basic new tools to society. It is important to note that without developing years of abstract theory with no applications in mind, these new results would not have been possible. Federal research funding continues to play a key role in these translational efforts.

One of the key outputs of this project is the training of graduate students, who have gone on to do research at universities and in industry and to teach at undergraduate-focused institutions. This funding also helped the PI give lecture series in Chile and Mexico, continuing strong American scientific engagement with countries in Latin America.

The PI is grateful to the NSF for this support, and to the US federal government for its continued funding for basic research and intellectual exploration.
